subject: Home & DIY
title: Sir John Harington's First Flush Toilet
description: A fast breakdown of Sir John Harington's First Flush Toilet for builders.

hook.text: Elizabeth I's godson built the first flush toilet in 1596. She put one in her palace. It took 200 years to catch on.

buildup.text: Harington designed a valve toilet with a raised cistern. Pulling a cord released water to flush waste into a cesspit.

discovery.text: He published a satire called 'The Metamorphosis of Ajax'â€”'jakes' meant toilet. The pun may be the origin of 'the john.'

twist.text: Without sewers, the flush toilet just moved the problem. Cesspits still needed emptying. The toilet outpaced its era.

climax.text: Only after Bramah's valve (1778) and London's sewers (1865) did flush toilets become practical at scale.

punchline.text: The toilet waited 270 years for the plumbing to catch up.

quiz.question: Why didn't Harington's 1596 flush toilet catch on for 200 years?
options: Without sewer systems, it just moved waste to cesspits that still needed emptying
The mechanism was too expensive for anyone but royalty
The Church banned it as immoral and ungodly
